item.description: Must resistance be active? A question arising from @BlueV2017’s differentiation between resistance vs existence. How does the differentiation between resistance and existence shift when considering the resistance inherent in a politics of refusal?
When living as a marginalized subject, is existence itself inherently resistant? What are the impacts of constructing subjects in opposition to their oppression?

consumerism often relies on white fascination with Black bodies White fascination with Black bodies and culture stems from the history of blackface minstrelsy, which was one of Americaâ€™s first widely-popular entertainment forms (@BlueV2017).

consumers want to feel victorious A claim from @BlueV2017 who considers the use of Black resistance as a marketing tactic. Since neutral and unmarked subjects are always signified as white, this demonstrates how Black resistance is appropriated by white consumers who project themselves into the victory of resistance.

listening as active and hearing as passive !Tom Rice (as cited in @BlueV2017) differentiates listening as an active engagement with sound and hearing as the experience of sound which one may not necessarily choose.
neutral and unmarked subjects are always signified as white thoughts & questions %% additional links & references A concept I found in @BlueV2017 but defined elsewhere.

noise is a form of othered sound !Mack Hagood, as cited in @BlueV2017, explores the problematization of noise as an impact of individualism in the neoliberal era, where sounds which are not personally chosen become constructed as the noise of the other.
silence as a Black survival technique @BlueV2017 describes how silence can be a form of Black radical self-possession by closing oneself off from the world (the “oppressive sound of whiteness” [p.
sound is always filtered through aspects of human subjectivity The ways that sound is heard and made meaningful is never separate from sociality.

sound is political @BlueV2017 shoes two ways that power rests with those who control sound: who gets to make what sounds where is determined by social norms and legislation (see also the way that sound is always filtered through aspects of human subjectivity and how noise is a form of othered sound) forms of authority use sound as a weapon, deterrent, and announcement of authority The politics of sound are embedded in a individualist philosophy which positions sound as against peace and individual rights.

item.title: audile technique
item.description: audile technique A concept from !Jonathan Sterne (as cited in @BlueV2017) which describes the practices of listening based in science and reason, encouraging that what is heard be rationalized.

item.title: commodified anger
item.description: commodified anger A form of anger which is projected on to the Black body, as the Black body stands as site of excess and lack of affect (@Palmer2017).

item.title: resistance vs existence
item.description: resistance vs existence @BlueV2017 argues that if Black subjects are considered disadvantaged, disempowered, and oppressed, all forms of Black innovation necessarily become understood through a lens of resistance.
